(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of A. Weber (team leader), and V. de Wit.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In August 2001, the Government of Pakistan (the Government) devolved 12 services to 
local governments as per the local government ordinance. Education and health services were 
devolved  to  district  governments,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation  to  tehsil  municipal 
administrations (TMAs). This devolved set-up provides opportunities to improve the substandard 
social services, but also poses major challenges given local political priorities, limited capacity, 
and financing constraints.  
 
2.  The Government of Balochistan has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide  assistance  for  improving  governance,  capacity,  and  financing  of  devolved  social 
services.  The  country  strategy  and  program  update  (2004–2006)1  provides  an  Asian 
Development Fund loan ($47 million) and an ordinary capital resources loan ($23 million) for the 
Balochistan Decentralized Social Services Program (DSSP) in 2005, with a project preparatory 
technical assistance (TA) in 2004 to carry out a feasibility study.2 The TA3 work will build on 
lessons from previous and ongoing sector investments that supported the social sectors, in 
particular the Decentralization Support Program, the Sindh DSSP,  and the public resource 
management programs that are designed to improve governance at macro and micro levels and 
place devolution on a firm financial footing.4 The TA framework is at Appendix 1. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND 
 
3.  The  socioeconomic  conditions  in  Balochistan’s  rural  communities  remain  extremely 
poor. Half of Balochistan’s people live in poverty, on less than a dollar a day (see also the 
summery  initial  poverty  and  social  analysis  at  Appendix  2).  They  face  harsh  conditions, 
including periodic drought and lack of employment. Among them, especially women lack assets 
and opportunities, have no social safety net, and are bound by practices that affect welfare and 
make it difficult for them to attend schools and clinics. Despite Government and external efforts 
to keep abreast of population growth (2.4% per year, compared to 1.7% in South Asia), only half 
the people have access to clean drinking water, half of school age children attend elementary 
school, and one third of children 12–23 months are immunized. However, education and 
employment of females are increasing. Another positive trend is the increasing capacity of 
communities to organize themselves and operate schools and water schemes.  
 
4.  Devolution is expected to increase community participation in basic social services so as 
to make these services more accountable, effective, and sustainable. Balochistan already has a 
network of schools, health care facilities, and water schemes, which, when properly functioning, 
could provide major benefits to a large number of poor. However, governance and financing of 
social services have been unsatisfactory for decades, and the devolution has brought about 
new  challenges  of  political  priorities  and  limited  capacity  that  need  to  be  addressed. 
Furthermore, the Balochistan government has set ambitious sector targets in line with the 
poverty reduction strategy and Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Social development,

5.  Education.  The  major  problem  is  lack  of  quality  of  instruction  due  to  teacher 
absenteeism, poor facilities, and lack of school supplies. Lack of access is a problem for certain 
remote populations as schools remain closed due to unavailability of teachers. Quality of 
education is the major factor resulting in low enrolment and high dropout rates. Moreover, lack 
of school infrastructure remains an issue. Expansion of elementary and secondary schools may 
be required in certain locations to accommodate remote areas and increasing enrolment of 
students, especially girls. Special efforts are needed to rationalize resources and to improve the 
internal efficiency of the education system. To make schools more relevant to the world of work, 
the Balochistan government is keen to improve technical education, expand the curriculum in 
secondary schools (including science and English), and introduce vocational streams at the 
middle school level. Other major developments are the increasing community involvement in 
school management and the hiring of location-specific contract teachers, both requiring capacity 
building and training. 
 
6.  Health.  The  past  focus  on  fragmented  interventions  has  resulted  in  a  general 
deterioration of health services. The Balochistan government wants to reestablish a system 
approach based on the principles of primary health care and integrated priority programs. The 
government has plans for reform initiatives with strong emphasis on autonomy of medical 
institutions, public-private partnership (including nongovernment organizations), and community 
involvement  through  health  boards.  The  province  is  making  efforts  to  convince  district 
governments to focus on improving the quality of services rather than expansion. The health 
department also wants to strengthen its role in policy development, sector regulation, health 
sector monitoring and quality control, and guidance and training of district health staff.  
  
7.  Water Supply and Sanitation. Priorities on this subsector are increasing coverage, 
strengthening  TMAs to plan and develop the services, and mobilizing communities to manage 
small-scale water and sanitation schemes on a self-sustaining basis (though full cost recovery 
may be difficult). The problems in expanding water supply include lack of readily available 
groundwater  of  adequate  quality,  overextraction,  and  high  operating  costs.  Devolution,  if 
combined with political commitment and funds, creates opportunities for sector development 
and reform whereby TMAs can begin to take responsibility for planning and implementing 
schemes to achieve wider access to clean water and sanitation. The Balochistan government is 
keen to improve governance of public water schemes, and work with the private sector, NGOs, 
and communities toward the MDG targets in the sector.  
 
8.  Crosscutting Features. One striking feature of Balochistan's health, education, water 
and sanitation subsectors is that the basic strategy followed since independence is unsuited to 
the communities that are resource poor, and live in dispersed, low density settlements. Sector 
policy has been "infrastructure driven," and the province struggles to meet the recurrent cost 
implications. There are three implications, especially for women and the poor. First, Balochistan 
has  numerous  unmaintained  physical  assets,  which  often  become  occupied  for  other, 
unintended  purposes,  while  large  areas  remain  underserved.  Second,  the  province  faces 
difficulties attracting and retaining, qualified front line workers (teachers, clinic attendants, water 
point operators, etc). Third, for the most part, the establishment of "central place" facilities— and 
the capture of most of the development and recurrent budget to do so—puts health, education 
and water beyond the reach of most of the poor. A sector policy will have to actively search for 
alternatives to serve the poor.

3
III.  ISSUES 
 
9.  Alternative Sector Policies. Because of the problems in policies,  policy reforms will 
need to consider alternate service provision policy strategies, which take into account the vast 
distances, dispersed population, and needs of the poor. The subsector strategies should bring 
about alternatives to the heavy infrastructure-driven policy and should identify ways to bring the 
services to the poor. Moreover, the strategies should include (i) improving cooperation between 
local and provincial governments to jointly manage social sector policy reforms, technical 
support, and monitoring; (ii) ensuring the efficiency of additional resources and accountability by 
experimenting, for example, with incentives to mobilize community support; (iii) exploring cost 
recovery possibilities; (iv) developing public-private partnerships to help finance and manage 
social services; (v) building capacity for districts to plan, budget, and deliver improved social 
services on an equitable basis, especially to rural areas; and (vi) prioritizing programs that help 
to achieve the MDGs. Social sector development depends on leadership capacity at district and 
community  levels,  including  the  relationship  of  nazim  and  district  chief  officers,  and  on 
competent staff and funds for operations. Strengthening local government capacity is labor 
intensive and must be continued for many years to come. 
 
10.  To Make Devolution Work. Devolution has fully empowered nazims and councilors to 
take charge of development at all three levels: district, tehsils, and union councils. However, 
many local government units (LGUs) lack political commitment and administrative capacity for 
social sector development. Decentralization requires provinces to transfer revenues to LGUs in 
the form of formula-driven block-grants, which are not earmarked for specific uses. LGUs now 
determine budgets and expenditures for most services, whereas the policy, standard-setting, 
and monitoring functions remain with the provincial and federal governments. Especially in 
Balochistan, the process of devolution will require support in order to be fully functional due to 
governance and service quality constraints and larger distances. In the end, the success of 
devolution will be measured by the public by improvements made in services. The Balochistan 
DSSP could substantially improve social services by helping improve local governments’ ability 
to plan and manage the social sector, put mechanisms in place to improve social sector 
financing and rationalize spending, increase community control over services and staff, and 
support provincial line departments with clear roles and better linkages.   
 
11.  To Involve Civil Society. Under devolution, the aim is for local governments and 
communities to take responsibility for social services. District governments and TMAs need to 
build links with communities, especially the community citizen’s boards. Over time, the boards 
will become capable of taking responsibility for service delivery, rather than the government. 
Social service delivery must be seen as a cooperative venture between all levels of government, 
communities, and the private sector, in support of low cost quality services. 
 
IV.  THE  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
12.  The purpose of the TA is to help the Balochistan government identify reforms necessary 
in public social services policy that will have major benefits for the poor in health, education, and 
water supply and sanitation. The TA will have three outputs: (i) design support mechanisms for 
devolved social services that will induce local governments and communities to make social 
services more  effective,  efficient,  equitable,  and  sustainable,  and  serve  as  a  vehicle  for 
coordination and monitoring; (ii) plan a program loan to establish these support mechanisms 
and the related reform agenda that will help to develop a selection of policies and reforms to be

4   
supported from loan proceeds, and plan technical support to improve social services based on 
local needs; and (iii) prepare a project for capacity building and program support, which is 
closely coordinated with the activities planned under the Balochistan Resource Management 
Program.  
 
13.  The TA will plan a program for Balochistan that targets the poor and is province-wide, 
demand-driven, and performance-based. All 26 districts in Balochistan will be assisted for an 
initial period of 3 years, with an emphasis on low cost services that will benefit many people, in 
particular the poor and women. While the program will be sectorwide, its design will ensure that 
it will only support subsectors and activities not otherwise funded by the government or other 
agencies. The program will allow flexible support according to local priorities but within a broadly 
agreed scope and set of conditions. The TA will also plan for extending into crosscutting areas, 
including  gender,  community  participation,  public-private  partnership,  environment,  and 
institutional development.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  TA consultants will (i) conduct a thorough analysis of the current situation in light of the 
local government ordinance and other government directives, and discuss the findings with 
stakeholders; (ii) recommend social sector reforms that will improve the basic conditions for 
improving social services under devolution; and (iii) design devolved social services activities to 
help local governments improve the quality of social services; build local capacity for service 
delivery; find ways to create and support public-private partnership; and support improvements 
to make the social sector more efficient, equitable, and sustainable.  
 
15.  The crosscutting specialists will develop a support structure and policy matrix to improve 
governance, capacity, and financing of social services at local government and community 
levels in close cooperation with the Balochistan Resource Management Program (BRMP). The 
sector specialists will focus on sector-specific interventions and reforms to strengthen social 
service  delivery.  In  education,  the  program  will  support  school  management  committees, 
schools and stipends for poor students, textbooks, teachers, and curriculum, to improve quality 
of education and enrolment. In health and population welfare, the scope may include support for 
health boards to improve facilities, revolving drug funds, and contracting of nurses and female 
health visitors to improve the quality of services. In water supply and sanitation, the scope may 
include support for (i) village development associations to improve small schemes, (ii) mapping 
and master plans, (iii) sector policies, and (iv) public-private partnership. ADB financing for the 
proposed program may follow one of several design modalities and the consultants will review 
ongoing ADB, Government, and other externally funded programs and projects to indicate how 
the proposed program will complement ongoing efforts.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $530,000 equivalent, of which $194,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $336,000 equivalent, the local currency cost. ADB will finance 
$400,000 covering the entire foreign exchange cost of $194,000 and $206,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. 
ADB will finance consulting services, production of reports, workshops, office equipment, and 
administration support services. The contribution by the government of Balochistan of $130,000 
equivalent in kind, will cover support for staff, use of facilities across sectors throughout the 
province, communications, and transport as indicated in the financing plan in Appendix 3. The

5
government  has been advised that approval of  the  TA does  not commit  ADB  to  finance any 
ensuing program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The Planning and Development Department (PDD), Balochistan, will be the Executing 
Agency for the TA.  A steering committee will be established to provide overall guidance to the 
TA  team.  The  committee,  chaired  by  the  additional  chief  secretary,  PDD,  will  comprise 
representatives from the departments of finance, education, local government, and health and 
population  welfare;  four  representatives  from  district  governments  and  TMAs;  and  two 
nongovernment representatives. At least two members will be female. The committee will be 
established at the beginning of the TA. It will meet at least once a month to monitor the TA and 
ensuring loan processing, so as to establish ownership by the government of Balochistan, 
provide guidance, and ensure that the design maximizes development impact for the poor.  
 
18.  The government will appoint a full-time program director before TA signing. The director 
will  also  attend  the  meetings  of  the  steering  committee.  All  concerned  departments  will 
designate counterpart staff to work on a part-time basis with the consultants. PDD will also 
provide necessary support staff. The government will prepare a document for internal approval 
before the TA with ADB signing. The program office will be established in the PDD after TA 
signing. The office will have utilities, furniture, and local telephone services. The TA will provide 
three computers, a printer, a facsimile machine, E-mail connection, two mobile phones, rented 
transport, and furniture as needed. Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB's 
guidelines for procurement. 
 
19.  The TA will use the services of three international (7 person-months) and four domestic 
(17 person-months) specialists. The domestic experts will include a governance and institutional 
development specialist and team leader (5 person-months); and a NGO and public-private 
partnership  expert  (4  person-months);  financial  expert,  economist,  and  team  coleader  (5 
person-months);  and  gender  and  social  participation  specialist  (3  person-months).  The 
international experts will include an education reform specialist (2 person-months), health sector 
reform specialist (3 person-months), and water supply and sanitation expert (2 person-months). 
All consultants will be recruited on an individual basis, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants  and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB  for the engagement of 
domestic consultants. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 4. 
 
20.  The consulting services under the TA will be carried out over a period of 5 months, from 
October 2004 to February 2005. The consulting team will submit an inception report within a 
month from the start of the TA, a preliminary report of the situation analysis and initial policy 
matrix within 3 months, the draft final report in the fourth month, and the final report within 5 
months from the start of the TA. The government of Balochistan and ADB will comment on the 
draft final report. The TA will include field visits, stakeholder mapping, and participatory planning 
to facilitate consensus building among a wide range of stakeholders (such as parents, teachers, 
health staff, and political and  administrative leaders at various levels). The consultants will 
organize at least three district workshops and one provincial workshop in Quetta to solicit views 
and discuss options and activities with stakeholders.  
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Balochistan Devolved Social Services Program, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The technical assistance will prepare a program, which will help to reform social services in the context of devolution 
with  special  emphasis  on  improving  access  for  the  poor.  To  assist  the  Government  in  achieving  its  human 
development goals, the project preparatory TA is giving high priority to improving access to social services. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis       Proposed Poverty Classification: CPI 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
  The incidence of poverty in Pakistan increased from 26.6% in fiscal year (FY) 1993 to 32.2% in FY1999 and 
the number of poor increased by over 12 million people during this period. Since  FY1999, economic growth has 
slowed further. Development spending has continued to decline, and that the incidence of poverty in Pakistan today is 
significantly likely to be higher than in FY1999. Poverty rose more sharply in the rural areas in the 1990s, and in 
FY1999 the incidence of rural poverty (36.3%) was significantly higher than urban poverty (22.6%). Inequality also 
increased in all four provinces, and FY1999 was clearly the most unequal year in all categories. In FY1997, the 
income share of the bottom 20% of households had declined to 6.9%, from 7.9% in FY1987, and the income share of 
the bottom 40% of households declined from 20% to 18%. During the same period, the ratio of the share of the top 
quintile to that of the bottom quintile increased to 6.5% from 5.2% for all areas. 
 
  The socioeconomic conditions in Balochistan remain extremely poor. Half of Balochistan’s people live in 
poverty, on less than $1 a day. They face harsh conditions, including periodic drought and lack of employment. Among 
them, women lack assets and opportunities, have no social safety net, and are bound by practices that affect welfare 
and make it difficult for them to attend schools and clinics. 
 
  Education is the most important factor that distinguishes the poor from the nonpoor. For example, the 
proportion of literate household heads in poor households is almost half that of nonpoor households. Poor households 
on average have 75% more children than the nonpoor households. Most of these children are not receiving any 
education, and thus the cycle of poverty is perpetuated. There is a strong correlation between household income and 
school enrollment. 
 
  Health indicators in Pakistan have improved somewhat during over the past decade, although they remain 
lower than indicators in other low-income countries. The infant mortality rate is estimated to have declined from 122 
per 1,000 live births in FY1991 to 89 per 1,000 live births by FY1999 according to the Pakistan Integrated Household 
Survey. The infant mortality rate was 93 per  1,000 live births for males and 85 for females, while for urban areas it 
averaged 73 per 1,000 live births as opposed to 95 per 1,000 live births for rural areas.  
 
  Maternal mortality rates are also very high, at about 340-400 per 100,000 births, largely because over 80% of 
total births take place at home, under the care of traditional birth attendants. Less than a third of expectant mothers 
typically go for prenatal checks, and this rate falls to barely a tenth for postnatal consultations.  
 
  The total fertility rate, improved somewhat declining from 6.8 births per woman in the mid 1980s to about 5.0 
births per woman by 1997. Once again, most of the reduction appeared to have taken place in urban areas, and has 
been largely attributed to an increase in the use of contraceptives. The contraceptive prevalence rate is estimated to 
be about 29% for urban areas, one of the lowest in Asia.  
 
  Full  immunization  rates  increased  from  45%  to  49%  based  on  recall  measures;  however,  these  fell 
considerably short of the 90% coverage targeted for 1998. Overall, the gender gap in this area was eliminated by 
FY1997, but reappeared in FY1999, when the difference in immunization between males and females was recorded at 
7 percentage points. The rural-urban gap narrowed from 9 to 6 percentage points over this time. The available data 
show a  strong correlation  between income and immunization,  as approximately 75%  of children in the upper income

quintile are fully immunized against only 25% in the bottom quintile.  
 
  Three  factors—communicable  infectious  diseases,  reproductive  health  problems  and  nutritional 
deficiencies—account for almost 60% of the burden of disease in Pakistan, when measured in terms of life-years lost. 
All of these are preventable or easily treatable problems, but the quality of health services is so inadequate that the 
incidence of such diseases remains high, and mortality rates remain high. An estimated 70% of all health facilities are 
in urban areas, and 70% of the national public health budget is spent on the construction and maintenance of hospital 
facilities, while primary health care is underfinanced. 
 
  Despite Government and external efforts to keep abreast of population growth, only half the people in 
Balochistan have access to clean drinking water, half of school age children attend elementary school, and one third 
of children 12–23 months are immunized. However, education and employment of females are increasing. Another 
positive trend is the increasing capacity of communities to organize themselves and operate schools and water 
schemes.  
 
  Devolution is expected to further increase community participation in basic social services so as to make 
these services more accountable, effective, and sustainable.

Specialist (international, 3 person-months), Water Supply and Sanitation Specialist 
(International, 2 person-months) 
 
 6.  Each specialist will have a minimum of 5 years experience in his or her field and be 
familiar with crosscutting issues of poverty reduction, gender, and environmental concerns. 
Each specialist will  
 
(i)  coordinate  sector  policies  closely  with  other  programs  and  projects  in  the 
subsector,  especially  the  BRMP  and  relevant    World  Bank  sector  reform 
programs (in the field of education); 
(ii)  collect information on the status of subsector indicators, including the Millenium 
Development Goals, for rural and urban populations by gender in each district, 
and estimate requirements to achieve increased targets; 
(iii)  based on stakeholder’s needs, prepare a selection of priority subsector policies 
in the subsector, including (a) alternative mechanisms of service delivery for a 
dispersed population, especially to the poor; (b) ways to ensure sustainability of 
services; (c) investigation of PPP possibilities; and (d) identification of capacity-
building  needs  in  order  to  implement,  manage  and  sustain  the  proposed 
services;  
(iv)  together with the financial specialist, for each proposed item, determine the 
quantity, unit cost, and total cost for each district; 
(v)  together with the PPP expert, identify opportunities and propose models for PPP 
to improve service delivery in districts and below; 
(vi)  for key outcomes in the subsector, develop monitoring indicators that correspond 
to the program impact (e.g., link program outcomes to increasing district targets); 
(vii)  work closely with economic and financial, governance, and poverty and social 
participation  consultants  on  crosscutting  issues  and  help  prepare  the  policy 
matrix  and  social  assessment  materials  linking  program  needs,  inputs,  and 
impacts with poverty reduction strategy; 
(viii)  prepare  sector  portions  of  the  inception  and  draft  reports  on  time  in  close 
cooperation with team leader; 
(ix)  ensure a consistent integrated approach to service delivery across sectors to 
ensure program focus on training needs, crosscutting issues, and cost effective 
approach; 
(x)  assist the gender and social participation specialist to determine gender issues, 
and help prepare the gender strategy; 
(xi)  together with the team leader, prepare a consultant task matrix, problem tree 
analysis, and local capacity constraint analysis to structure report writing;   
(xii)  conduct  regional  and  provincial  workshops  covering  all  districts  to  get 
stakeholder participation and ownership in setting priorities in the sector; 
(xiii)  consult stakeholders through field visits and regional workshops to ensure their 
points of view are incorporated in program activities, training programs, and 
schemes designed to improve social service delivery; and  
(xiv)  assist ADB in any other assignments as may be reasonably expected within the 
scope of work.
